She now needs a loan for US $250, which will be repaid in 3 months, for material for making her outfits. With your help, she will make her business grow.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva volunteer.

Crisanta desde muy pequeña aprendió a bordar, gracias a las enseñanzas de su hermana, ella empezó haciendo bordados que le encargaban para los trajes regionales, pero al ver que era buen negocio decidió dedicarse no solo a bordar, sino a elaborar ella misma los trajes, es así como desde hace 10 años se dedica a la elaboración y venta de trajes regionales, esto le deja buenos ingresos ya que la gente los usa en eventos del pueblo asi como en celebraciones especiales.

Ella ahora necesita un prestamo por US $250 que pagara en 3 meses para tener material para la elaboracion de sus trajes. Con tu ayuda ella podra hacer crecer su negocio.

loans.use: Buy materials for her work.

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina, single and 25 years old, sells footwear for both women and men. She buys her products from Lima, and because of the flexible schedule that her business allows, is able to continue her higher education studies. Rosalina now needs a loan of $350, money which she will invest in the purchase of shoes.

As a member of the Village Bank Prosperity, Rosalina has learned many things about how to educate her children and maintain their house. She dreams of expanding her business, having an established store with a greater variety of shoes, and finishing her professional studies.

loans.use: To purchase shoes for her business.

loans.name: Efua

texts.en: Afua K. sells palm oil. She is married, but her husband's income is not sufficient for Afua and her six children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits. She is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her business selling palm oil.

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort Y. sells gari, a popular local dish. She is married, but her husband's income is not sufficient for Comfort and her three children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits. She is asking for 500 GHS ($475.00) of additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her business selling gari.

loans.name: Ines

texts.en:
Ines, a member of the Village Bank Retoño, is 35 years old, married, and has five children. Ines has a car washing business at her house, and at the beginning she had very few clients. However, thanks to the great service she offers and the quality of her products, she has been able to develop a client base surpassing all other car washing services. Furthermore, Ines dedicates much of her leisure time to her business. She now needs a loan of $425 to renovate the floor of her car wash so that the runoff doesn’t infiltrate her home.

Ines´s dreams are to have a stock of car lubricants, continue developing her business, and have her children grow up to be professionals.

loans.use: To renovate the floor of her car wash in order to avoid infiltration into her home.

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en:
Francisca, who belongs to the Village Bank Arco Iris, is 50 years old, separated, and has two children. She sells groceries, vegetables, fruit, and clothes at the fairs around the region and also buys cheese and cereal from the fairs which she then sells at the markets in Ayacucho.  

Francisca now needs a loan of $575, money which she will invest in the purchase of lingerie, fruit, and groceries.

Her dreams are for her children to finish their studies and that she will one day have an established store in the city of Ayacucho.

loans.use: To purchase lingerie, fruit, and groceries.

loans.name: Ana María

texts.en:
Ana Maria, a member of the Village Bank Arco Iris, is 37 years old, married, and the mother of two children. She lives in the district of San Juan Bautista, a province of Huamanga. Ana Maria has a store in her home where she sells groceries, meat, and vegetables; she also has a smaller store where she sells vegetables, chicken and condiments. She is able to maintain both businesses with the help of her daughter. 

Ana Maria now needs a loan of $350, money which will be invested in the purchase of rice, sugar, and oil. 

Her dreams are to develop her business and to give her children a good education.

loans.use: To purchase rice, sugar, and oil.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her business selling maize and gari.

loans.name: Dorothy

texts.en: Dorothy E. sells clothing material. She is married, but her husband's income from his own sales is not sufficient for Dorothy and her two children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits. She is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her business selling clothing materials.

loans.name: Esabel

texts.en:
Esabel, a member of the Village Bank Kusikuy, is 24 years old, married, and the mother of one daughter. A resident of Sr. de Quinuapata, Esabel makes hand-woven sweaters out of wool at the request of her clients. Her products are also sold at the fairs, from which she also buys cheese to sell to stores in Ayacucho. 
Esabel now requests a loan of $350, money which will be invested in the purchase of the best wool and cheese.

Her dreams are to expand her business and provide her daughter with a good education.

loans.use: To purchase wool and cheese.

loans.name: Leonarda

texts.en:
Leonarda, who belongs to the Village Bank Arco Iris, is 35 years old, married, and has three children. She lives in the neighborhood called Yuracc Yuracc which in Quechua means White White. Leonarda visits different fairs of the region where she sells fruit and vegetables and also buys cereals, cheeses, and other products to sell at the Nery García market and house to house. She now requests a loan of $700, money which she will invest in the purchase of wheat, corn, barley and cheese.

Leonarda dreams that she will have sufficient savings to allow her children to study and achieve professional careers, and that she will expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase wheat, corn, barley and cheese.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en: Evelyn B. sells cosmetics and provisions. She is married, but her husband's income from construction work is not sufficient for Evelyn and her two children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits. She is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase more cosmetics and other provisions for her store.

loans.name: Noemí

texts.en:
Noemi, a member of the Village Bank Arco Iris, is 36 years old, married, and has four children. Noemi visits the fairs of the region where she buys cereal, cheese, hens, and other products to sell in the markets in the city of Ayacucho. Furthermore, she makes cereals out of flour as well as a variety of breads in a rented oven, selling them in the city of Pisco, which is six hours from Ayacucho. Noemi also sells firewood from her home. She needs a loan of $350, money which she will invest in the purchase of flour, wheat, barley and corn.

Noemi´s dreams are that her children become professionals and that she have an established business in her house so she can stay close to her children.

loans.use: To purchase flour, wheat, barley and corn.

loans.name: Dios Es Esperanza (God Is Hope) Group 1

texts.en:
Maria has two children aged 30 and 29 and three grandchildren aged 4, 5 and 5.  Maria owns a ventorrillo (or little store) where he sells yams, plantains, potatoes and other agricultural products. He obtains the vegetables by traveling to the country.  Maria has already successfully completed four loans with Esperanza International, and with a fifth loan, he hopes to be able to expand his business, afford more necessities and provide his grandchildren with a good education.  

Note: This is a group loan.

loans.use: To develop his business and provide for his grandchildren.

loans.name: Faustina

texts.en:
Faustina, a member of the Village Bank Retoño, is 42 years old, married, and has three children. Faustina visits the different fairs of the regions where she buys cereals and potatoes, then sells the cereals in the Nery Garcia market. She dries the potatoes (used for many typical Peruvian dishes) and also buys already-dried potatoes, later selling them in cities on the coast. Faustina needs a loan of $700, money which she will invest in the purchase of potatoes by the sack.

Faustina´s dreams are to help her children become professionals, develop her business, and improve her living conditions.

loans.use: To invest in the purchase of potatoes by the sack.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence M. sells slippers and other provisions. She is married, but her husband's income from fishing is not sufficient for Florence and her four children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits. She is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more slippers and other provisions to sell.

loans.name: Mercedes Rocio

texts.en:
Mercedes, who belongs to the Village Bank Alegria Huamanga, lives with her boyfriend, is 24 years old and has one child. Mercedes has a fishery – a store or restaurant where she sells shellfish and fish from a rented space that is close to a big market in the city of Ayacucho. Furthermore, she has a motor taxi that she rents to provide public transportation through the city. Mercedes is requesting a loan of $350 in order to purchase articles with which to decorate her restaurant.

Mercedes´s dreams are to offer the best life possible to her child, develop her business by opening more branches, and have her own house.

loans.use: To purchase articles with which to decorate her restaurant.

loans.name: Dios Es Esperanza (God Is Hope) Group 3-4

texts.en: Jimena has three children, ages 7, 4 and 14 months.  She owns a small business selling chicken, beef and vegetables.  Jimena has already completed four loans with Esperanza., and with her fifth one hopes to get that much closer to expanding her business, owning her own home and providing an education for her children.

loans.use: To develop her business and provide for her three young children.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Esperanza International, a partner of HOPE International - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en: Rebecca A. sells drinks. She is married, but her husband's income from teaching is not sufficient for Rebecca and her two children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits. She is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her business selling soft drinks.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Christian Rural Aid Network (CRAN) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Cristo Es Esperanza (Christ Is Hope) Group 1

texts.en: Francia has five children ranging in age from 12 to 25.  She owns a small shop selling vegetables and other necessities to her neighbors, and she has already paid back five loans to Esperanza International.  With this next loan, Francia hopes to continue working and developing her business so that she can put food on the table and provide for her children’s education.

loans.use: To expand her business and provide a good education for her children.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en: Joseph A. sells second-hand goods. He is single and his income is not sufficient for his expenses. Demand for his goods is high, and he is looking to expand his business to increase his profits. He is asking for additional capital to expand his business.

loans.use: To expand his business selling second-hand goods.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Christian Rural Aid Network (CRAN) - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Union Y Progreso (Unity And Progress) Group 5

texts.en:
Margarita, who owns a small shop selling undergarments, is the proud mother of two children, ages 10 and 16. She has already paid back five loans to Esperanza International, and with her next loan wants to continue expanding her business so that she and her family can have a better life. Margarita hopes her children will get the best education possible and that she will be able to provide for them so that they can pursue good careers. She is very thankful to Esperanza International for the support and stability it has allowed her and her family.

Note: This is a group loan. Also, the young man wearing red in the picture is standing in for his mother Elena, who was not able to make it to the meeting.

loans.use: To expand her business and provide for her two children.

loans.name: Gifty

texts.en: Gifty M. sells provisions and groceries. She is single and her income is not sufficient for Gifty and her child. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits. She is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her business selling provisions and groceries.

loans.name: Kwamina

texts.en: Kwamina A. sells shoes, ladies wear, and sandals. He is married, but his wife's income from selling goods is not sufficient for Kwamina and his two children. Demand for his goods is high, and he is looking to expand his business to increase his profits. He is asking for additional capital to expand his business.

loans.use: To expand his business selling shoes, ladies wear, and sandals.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Christian Rural Aid Network (CRAN) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Theresah

texts.en: Theresah A. sells maize, cassava and plantains. She is married, but her husband's income from farming is not sufficient for Theresah and their two children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is requesting a loan of $475 to expand her business to increase her profits.

loans.use: To purchase more goods.

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en: Ekua T. sells jewelry and meat. She is single, and her income is not sufficient for Ekua and her two children. Demand for her goods is high, so she is requesting a loan of $400 to expand her business to increase profits.

loans.use: To purchase more goods for sale.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Cecilia B. sells clothing that she sews, as well as rice and soup. She is single and her income is not sufficient for her and her child. Demand for her goods is high, and she is requesting a loan of $400 to expand the business to increase her profits.

loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Abena

texts.en: Abena B. sells clothes and materials. She is married, but her husband's income from his job as an accountant is not sufficient for her and their four children. Since demand for her goods is high,  she is requesting a loan of $400 to expand the business to increase her profits.

loans.use: To expand her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Christian Rural Aid Network (CRAN) - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Martin

texts.en: Martin B. sells household goods. He is married, but income from the business is not sufficient  for his wife and two children. Demand for his goods is high, so he is requesting a loan of $475  to expand his business to increase  profits.

loans.use: To expand his business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Christian Rural Aid Network (CRAN) - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en: Gladys B. sells clothing and shoes. She is single, and her income is not sufficient for her and her child. Demand for her goods is high, so she is requesting a loan of $475 to expand the business to increase her profits.

loans.use: To expand her business.
